oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of a World War II salvage drive for rubber
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph depicts a salvage drive taking place on a street in Knoxville, Tenn. Featured in the photo is a downtown Knoxville street with large tires lined up down the length of the street. There are three men and one police officer standing beside the tires holding a sign that reads ""State of Tennessee enters 'Treausure Hunt' for Salvage Rubber"".

During World War II, Americans were frequently called upon to salvage raw materials for the war effort. Frequently, Tennesseans participated in salvage drives to collect materials such as rubber, paper, silk, cooking fat, iron, steel, aluminum, and more. Salvage drives represented a way that Tennesseans could participate in the war effort at home and also built a sense of patriotism among the home front.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: World War, 1939-1945; Rationing-- United States
